w:r.w:t: based on Axis 1, Competitiveness Operational Programme financing.
The need for systems capable of
analytics is ubiquitous in a global information society.

With the recent advances in the areas of predictive machine learning models and massive parallel computing a new set of resources is now potentially available for the computer science community in order to research and develop new truly intelligent and innovative
applications. In the current paper we present the principles, architecture and current experimentation results for an online platform capable of both hosting and generating
artificial intelligence, machine learning, virtual desktop, predictive analytics
The entire field of Artificial Intelligence tends to become more and more about improving predictions and predictive models as Goldfarb et al
argue in the paper “Managing the Machines”. Predictive modelling can now be used for extremely varied tasks ranging from constructing expert system chat-bots
based on Long Short Term Memory deep recurrent neural networks that would use natural language
capability (reading and writing) up to melanoma recognition in dermoscopy images
In our paper, we will propose several approaches:
services based model for the deployment of model training and prediction on GPU mas
sive parallel computing backend. The GPU based parallel computing environment will enable to construct and optimize a GPU-optimized set of machine learning algorithm implementations.
automatic software design, development and deployment for user experience modules based on a pipeline shallow machine learning model
ying framework for generation and hosting predictive analytics applications

Within out paper we will argue that our proposed research and experimentation will fuel the development and implementation of a production-grade system capable of addressing in the same time the needs of several categories of customers such as
users in need of a online application marketplace fully oriented on predict
oftware developers in need of a legacy apps automatic software translation tools including
scientific users both from academic and commercial environment looking for a
online application framework and execution environment
in order to conduct predictive experiments in areas such as healthcare, finance and environment;
Our work relates to the most recent advances both in the field of High Performance
, particularly in the areas of machine learning model deployment on massive parallel processing infrastructures based on numerical computing cores.
The usage of GPU based computing is currently mostly applied in deep learning – both research experiments and production development

little to no attention is given to the employment of GPU parallel computing resources in shallow machine learning techniques such as decision trees, multi-variate linear and logistic regression, Naive-Bayes models. Nonetheless the current advances and the state-of-the-art prediction scores achieved by the deep learning scientific experiments give little room to further scientific development and advances of known shallow models techniques. Even more, companies such as Microsoft, Google or IBM currently propose online framework-engines that allow on-demand web-based prediction model creation and experimentation
entirely used for off-line training and prediction experiments, running on CPU based infrastructures.

presented aspects into account we are proposing a set of new modern approaches that will potentially empower shallow machine learning models with the capability using GPU based parallel computing resources.
Our approach fully relates with the current state-of-the-art in the area of GPU-based tensor computation frameworks currently employed in Deep Learning frameworks
nother of the supporting aspects that we will use in our approach is based on the most important features of shallow machine learning models: the ability of the
. This ability of shallow machine learning models such as linear models or decision trees models is certainly available
at the expense of prediction power shown by deep models
The proposed architecture is based on our previous work conducted in the area of automatic software application migration and machine-learning assisted automatic programming
combined with the latest advances in
large-scale machine learning on heterogeneous distributed systems
the following desiderates during the production phase of our project:
Create a scalable architecture for a user-friendly online environment where external users will be able to quickly generate and customize application starting from existing legacy apps;
Combine the power of the automatic application generation features with template-based models in order to create a
horizontal application repository that will include apps such as

(a) multi-vertical customer churn prediction models; (b) multi-vertical customer behavior inference model; (c) business flow generated data exploration stub apps; (d) machine learning stub/template applications

that will continuously grow by accommodating machine learning augmented apps in areas such as medical diagnostics inference/prediction, financial predictive analytics, environment inferential models. The proposed scientific apps will be developed within the “Cloudifier” community and will fully utilize the
scalable GPU-augmented machine learning template models;
execution framework based on REST services
generated within a provisioned Cloud infrastructure
consisting of template-developed business applications and scientific experiments;
REST based massive parallel computation services

Based on the fact that one of our paper areas of innovation is the augmentation of shallow machine learning models with parallel processing techniques based on GPU processing, we are proposing a REST based service for parallel computation on GPU backend. At present time, based on our knowledge,

the advancement of GPU based hardware infrastructures capable of delivering massive parallel computing for machine learning tasks at very low costs has only been exploited by the area of deep learning and deep neural networks in particular
. Our proposal addresses this gap between the available computation resources for deep learning and the ones available for scientific shall
have been arguing that shallow models can achieve similar results with deep models if sufficient data is provided, such as the famous quote
“We don’t have better algorithms. We just have more data.”

In our proposed approach for advancing shallow machine learning by GPU parallel computing augmentation we will argue that shallow model’s pipelines can achieve comparable results with deep learning models for various applications. Although most of the state-of-the-art research in the area of machine learning is focused on deep learning models
the classic machine learning models with shallow hidden layer structure
two main characteristics that deep models lack: self-explain ability and algorithmic robustness for online and real-time environments.

For large scale datasets such as those met in BigData analytics such operations are extremely time and resource consuming. Nevertheless, the employment of the GPU kernel based computation parallelism will enable this operation to be executed in a time dramatically lower than with classical CPU approach.
code will be left for a lower level tensor computation framework, namely TensorFlow
, a Open Source framework already established as a industry state-of-the-art standard
programming framework for expressing machine learning algorithms combined with a backend implementation for executing such algorithms in various heterogenous
computing environments. One of the most important features of TensorFlow is the automatic deployment of tensor grap
hs calculation on multiple GPUs, although without high-level resource allocation mechanics.
As previously mentioned, in the current paper we will present a REST

approach for cloud computing based provisioning of parallel computation services. This approach will enable the implementation and consumption of a web based service that will have the following generic algorithm ba
For each Kernel, Data pair in Request
by value or by reference from external source

The actual GPU execution strategy of the off-loaded kernels will be based on an adaptive algorithm that will take into consideration server-load, task complexity and GPU load/preparation overhead.

Off-load overhead time + time until devices are available
Finally, the entire predictive analytics REST webservice and app repository is based on a simple algorithm
Training new models based on post data or externally available data
Prediction/inference based on trained models (via a
The actual messages that are passed between clients and the REST server are simple JSONs in the following format:
HANDLE: ModelHandle, # not NULL if requesting results
DATA: DataDict, # data dictionary containing predictor variables, targets (if avaiable) with actual data or link to external data repository
MODEL: ModelName # a model (specific or generic) to be trained (if model HANDLE is not yet available)
For a clearer understanding of the mechanics behind the proposed architecture we will present the full algorithm cycle for the case of requesting the training of a recommender system (
Parse the transactional data dict and download data from external source if needed
Allocate resources and request training of
generated apps and template-based apps. The generated apps will actually be the results of our automatic software migration engine
, fully hosted within the execution environment proposed by our
purpose is to construct a continuously growing repository of

online “skeleton” apps that have been designed for a particular horizontal purpose within the area of predictive analytics. The user will be able to configure a certain template or propose a new template for online publication and crowd-testing.
The proposed template apps cover the following types of predictive analytics models:
Multi-variate machine learning regression model templates for product/sales recommendations
Multi-variate machine learning classification model templates for customer churn prediction
Unsupervised machine learning clustering model templates for customer segmentation

Finally, both the automated apps and the template based app creation features of our user apps repository will facilitate the fast-development and deployment of customer predictive analytics applications.

he business apps and research experiments repositories will host various predictive analytics online applications that will be able to run the proposed machine learning models within the proposed GPU processing backend.
will contain applications that have been designed/developed using the API provided by the our cloud machine learning execution framework.
It is our objective to transform the experimental outcomes of the
paper and the underlining architecture into a full community and crowed-sourced repository of both scientific and business-oriented machine learning experiments.

This objective will effectively transform the proposed applications repository in a incubatory for intelligent predictive analytics applications. In order to achieve this, we will address two different types of communities: the auto-generated applications community (User Apps) and the externally developed and uploaded applications community (Experiments).

The main difference between the User Apps repository and the Business and Research Experiments repository is that in the first case the platform users are fully relying on our cloud architecture for the entire development lifecycle of the predictive analytics app. In the second
the platform users are externally developing the predictive analytics apps based on the resources provided by our cloud framework.
areas of automatic legacy software migration for the User Apps repository and also in the area of development and deployment of predictive analytics experiments.
Automatic legacy software migration and provisioning
of desktop-based ready-to-migrate applications has been constructed consisting of applications written in FoxPro, Visual Basic, Visual C++. For this particular set of
we are using our automated migration software
existing source code of the legacy
In this particular area we are currently conducting research and experimentation both with functional legacy applications and with partially functional applications (or even user interface scraps).
The experiment validation is based on the actual legacy application source code (where available).
The source code is necessary for the actual validation of resulting automated migration inferential process.

is currently limited to translation and REST provisioning of machine learning algorithms such as:
GPU optimized SoftMax, linear/logistic regression for large datasets
GPU optimized recommender systems based on matrix factorization techniques
As an actual result example, we will describe the machine learning recommender system inference performance. O
Our target was to produce recommender system inferences for the following experiment:
Finally, we managed to produce the full-batch inference

a classic architecture with 32 CPU and 64GB RAM. For this particular benchmark, we used a classic matrix factorization based recommender system with BoW-based engineered predictor variables and generated 2,000,000 different shallow models (1 model for each customer). We ran the same approach within
parallel computing for the inference process on all available CPU cores
Table 1: GPU vs CPU performance comparison
for the single case inference where only one
model is employed the classic CPU approach wins mostly due to the overhead of GPU device placement of the operations. However, for 2,000,000 models
batch-inference, the GPU-optimized approach clearly leverages the 2500+ numerical computations cores and manages to surpass the CPU based parallel computing approach.
Finally, we will mention that our current focus

to research new GPU optimization and implementation approaches for other shallow machine learning algorithms than we currently have implemented. All these methods will be freely provisioned and available for academic purposes though the proposed REST framework.
